awd_titl_txt: Holocene Biogeography of Mangroves Along the Gulf of Mexico Coast: Past, Present, and Future
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will investigate past and present environmental conditions and mangrove distributions and provide predictive assessments of the future distributions of mangroves along the Gulf of Mexico coast.  Mangrove expansion in the Gulf coastal region is a recent phenomenon, and the new insights from this project will provide a more comprehensive understanding of past environmental patterns and future expansion areas based on climatic fluctuations.  The project will expand knowledge regarding how feedbacks from human-environment interactions affect wetland vegetation shifts in a region characterized by increasing environmental uncertainty.  Project benefits to the broader community will include a better understanding of mangrove expansion to coastal area residents and communities and proactive water resources management planning by appropriate coastal federal and state agencies.  The project will support science education in local schools through collaboration with the Coastal Roots Program at Louisiana State University.  The investigators will participate in workshops with Louisiana school teachers and engage them in communicating scientific knowledge about environmental changes and mangrove expansion.

Mangroves play a critical role in global carbon sequestration and provide many important ecosystem services.  Long-term quantitative data on the distribution and abundance of mangroves along the U.S. Gulf Coast have been largely inadequate.  This project will produce high-resolution multi-proxy stratigraphic records from four critical mangrove habitats to elucidate the changing distribution of all mangrove species along the Gulf Coast over the last 2,000 years. The investigators will focus on three core questions: (1) How has the distribution and abundance of mangroves changed in response to Holocene environmental and climatic variations along the U.S Gulf Coast?  (2) Which environmental variables are most likely to be responsible for controlling the spatial distribution of mangroves in the U.S?  (3) What will be the northern ranges of different mangrove species by the end of the 21st century?  The investigators will use a combination of palynological, X-ray fluorescence, and loss-on-ignition analytic techniques and radiocarbon dating to reconstruct the Holocene vegetation changes and sedimentary history of mangrove habitats along the U.S Gulf Coast.  Cellular automata modeling techniques will be used to predict the future ranges of different mangrove species by the end of the 21st century.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The modern distribution of mangroves shows a classical disjunct distribution along the northern Gulf of Mexico Coast of the U.S.  All three species of mangroves occur continuously from the Florida Everglades to Cedar Keys, but scattered colonies of black and red mangroves are present only in Apalachicola, Florida, and only black mangrove is present in the Mississippi Delta region of Louisiana.  Due to the lack of Holocene paleoecological data along the Gulf Coast it was unknown whether the disjunct distribution is a result of recent long-distance dispersal in response to climatic warming, or range contraction from a former widespread distribution attributable to climatic cooling during the Little Ice Age.  This project reconstructed the Late Holocene history of mangroves along the northern Gulf Coast by means of palynological and stratigraphic analyses of sediment cores collected from coastal wetlands from Florida to Texas to document the timing of mangrove colonization and population dynamics at each site.  Our multi-proxy datasets indicate that mangroves arrived in the Everglades, Florida, at least 3800 years ago as sea level rose. Red mangrove arrived at Port Charlotte about 2500 years ago, followed by black mangrove at ~2000 yr BP and white mangrove only a few hundred years ago.  Black mangrove then spread to Cedar Keys, Florida, at ~1300 yr BP, followed by white mangrove and red mangrove.  Black and red mangroves migrated to Dog Island, Apalachicola, Florida, less than 200 years ago, and to adjacent St. George Island only a few decades ago.  Black mangrove is the only species that reached Port Fourchon, Louisiana, about a century ago and has proliferated since then.  Mangroves never colonized the coastal areas of southwestern Louisiana during the Holocene.  Our paleoecological data do not support the range contraction hypothesis.  Instead, they are consistent with the scenario that mangroves migrated continuously from the Everglades to Cedar Keys by diffusion along the coast but were dispersed to southern Louisiana and Apalachicola by jump dispersal. 

This project also spun off a fruitful international collaboration with a Brazilian research team to investigate the effects of extreme weather events on the survival and recovery of mangroves in Louisiana, the northernmost distribution of mangroves in North America, by means of state-of-the-art remote sensing techniques.  Drone surveys, coupled with high-resolution satellite data, were used to document the patterns of mangrove mortality and their rates of recovery in response to the 2017/2018 winter freezing event and the direct landfall of Hurricanes Zeta (2020) and Ida (2021) around Port Fourchon.  The results show that while winter freezes caused ~90% mortality to mangrove populations, direct hit by a cat 4 hurricane caused only minor damages (~5.5%) to black mangroves, and only those growing on the outer edges of a mangrove stand.  Thus, this finding reveals that winter freezes, rather than intense hurricanes, can do more damage to the survival and sustainability of black mangrove at its northern limit of distribution on the Gulf Coast.  This point is important and novel, because it implies that climate warming with milder winters?not enhanced hurricane activity resulting from global warming?is the main factor controlling the future spread and proliferation of mangrove populations along the Gulf Coast.

This project has resulted in the publication of 17 papers in prestigious journals.  As a result of our very successful fieldwork and productive multi-proxy analyses in the laboratory, 23 new multi-proxy paleoecological (palynological) records have been produced or published from Florida to Louisiana and Texas.  These new records have filled a huge gap in the paleoecological data network for the entire Gulf of Mexico Coast, thereby completely changing the scientific landscape for the Gulf Coast region in the fields of Holocene biogeography, coastal paleoenvironmental changes, and mangrove paleoecology.  They provide new and critical datasets for understanding the Holocene biogeography of mangroves along the Gulf Coast and create new knowledge on the Holocene history of environmental changes relating to species migration, climatic changes, sea level rise, extreme events, and coastal ecosystem development.

In addition to spinning off a new international collaboration with a Brazilian research team, this project also provided research and training opportunities for three postdocs, three Ph.D. students, a M.S. student, and two undergraduate students at LSU as they participated in field work, laboratory work, and data analysis.
